ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 2 hrs for the one class
I had already taken many of the required courses online for other classes or for my job so my workload for this course was substantially reduced. Also, it was a 1-time class.
3 hours X1
Only one meeting for 2 hours.
1 hour, one time.
1 hour
NA
N/A
0 hours. This is just a 2 hours seminar
Just maybe 3-5 hours the one week that we had this class.
The research ethics seminar was only one day in February, so we spent about 3 hours total.
3 hrs (to complete the required assignments)
I spent about 4 hours completing the certifications and writing my makeup paper.
2 hours
7-8 hours on the week after the seminar.
8 hours during the weeks around the seminar.
Only about 2hrs during one week.
4 hours in total
1 hour
i spent about 6 hrs on the course

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: fine, i knew a lot of the information already though.
Why make us sit through a painful seminar? Just require all students to do the online modules before starting Yale.

This was a fine introduction to research ethics. I think many of our classes at YSPH cover ethics in some form or another so this was a fine supplement. I feel like I have a good basic understanding of research ethics.
For students in the AP program, this seminar was a waste of time. We have all done research before or had medical ethics courses. There should be some sort of mechanism to test out of this seminar.

It is ridiculous that such an important concept is consolidated into a two-hour lecture. I took an entire semester class on Public Health Ethics in undergrad, and that is how it should be taught here. The material was not helpful and it seemed as if they just wanted to 'check the box' that they had taught it. Really embarrassing that YSPH would conduct itself in this manner.

More direct examples of when we might need IRB approval would have been helpful (i.e. if you are giving surveys, this is what you need to do, if you are working with patients, this is what you need to do).
This was some course we had to take to be MPH students, it provided no value as it was redundant with a guest lecture we had in another course.

I dont know what the point of the lecture was. Instead, we should be required to do all the online exams together. I understand the importance of knowing HIPAA information and everything else we tested for, but the lecture seemed to be an inconvenient waste of time. Khave did a really good job though, this is not a comment on him.
I didnt go to the lecture. I wrote a paper. A lot of the websites we were meant to take the tests on weren't working properly.
N/A
The course is mandatory so nothing can really be said of whether it was worthwhile or not. I thought that it should have been broken down into smaller groups, rather than the plenary session.
2 hours was plenty of time for the seminar and the most important concepts were covered.
Good, thorough, efficient vehicle for covering the required material. Stay the line!
It's not really a class just one time seminar.
Required 2 hr seminar on research ethics. Relatively painless. The IRB section is somewhat informative for people who will have to go through that process.
The online certificates taught us all the information that the lecture presented, so the lecture was superfluous, but it was only taught once in the semester, so if there is a lecture, no big.
Given that I had to complete most of this course's requirements for my volunteer work, this was not necessary for me.
Does this class really apply to HPA and HMP students who aren't going to do summer research?
Why isn't there a whole course on research ethics that is required? This is such an important topic and really integral part of research.
This course didn't teach any new material---all material had been covered in other courses.

This was a one-time class which was interesting, but not particularly useful for me because I don't plan on doing research. With that said, though, it's probably best that a graduating MPHer has these certificates.
It was a waste of time.
It was a very helpful course to better understand research ethics and how to properly coordinate research involving human subjects.

Strengths- good overview of research ethics and expected ethical behaviour of individuals in Yale that are carrying out researchWeakness- The in class meeting could have been spread over two or three class meeting

Epstein committed two classes and a guest lecturer to IRB/Ethics therefore this was an unnecessary review that stressed and inconvenienced students rather than informed them.The powerpoint slides were disjointed and the instructors were not formally introduced. One slide, Belmont Report: beneficience, justice, respect could have sufficed.
The ethics lecture was interesting as far as ethics lectures go.
We only met once for this course, but I did feel it was useful.I have had little exposure to research using human subjects, so it was a good introduction to the ethical protocol for that.
the course gave an important introduction to ethical issues and IRB procedures. however, perhaps the course could have been given as an online tutorial or shorter informational training.
generally pointless, but at times had interesting discussion
Decent
I wasn't able to attend the lecture so had to make up the work.
good
it improves students' awareness of many ethical issues which is essential to public health researchers and managers.
The course was helpful in opening the eye of everyone to the constant debates that occur in research ethics and the protocols and procedures that must be considered when doing research.

This was only taken since it was a requirement. The majority of the material covered was not new to me, and I did not learn much from the session. Filling out the required online courses was a waste of time unless required to do my own research projects.
Good. It may be better to have the course more than once though as i felt little was learnt during the class.
I have a very strong background in research ethics so it's hard to say how beneficial this class is. I'm sure that for students with no background, this course provided a good foundation.
Good introduction to IRB and related research issues
I would prefer to just do the assignments and not have the lecture part of the course.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  decent, got the information across efficiently
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is awesome! He makes things so easy to understand and he is so up-front about his expectations. As one of his students I really appreciate that about him.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  engaging lecturer
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Good instructor and very interesting. Not his fault that the course was only a one-time off affair.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great professor.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  He's great! Perfect fit to teach this one-time course.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kinda hard to take the guy seriously when even he was rushing to attend the Happy Hour right after the Seminar.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  He did a great job.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Well-informed, courteous gentleman who covered all the material succinctly and clearly. Keep up the good work, Dr Khoshnood.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  He's really inspiring and a great professor.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh was a fine instructor for this seminar.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great job
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Good use of comic relief to introduce the course. Tried to balance lecture and discussion. Very open to questions.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  This should be a required semester long course. I want to learn more about public health research ethics, and a few students I feel could really use the training.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is an excellent professor.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  He's great - although sometimes a bit wordy.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  He is awesome!! The class was not.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Dr. Khoshnood is an excellent professor and helped to make the material more interesting.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I enjoyed the disease/study-specific narratives that described challenges to the Belmont Report and international discrepancies between ethics review boards.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is an engaging and funny lecturer. This is an ethics seminar so we didn't really have much more interaction than that.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I felt he did a good job expressing the importance of conducting ethical research and how to effectively do that while conducting scientifically-sound research as well.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  The instructor was clear, audible, and well prepared. His slides were clear and understandable.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kave = amazing
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Solid
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  good
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Excellent
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh was great at getting people involved in the seminar making it more of a conversation then a lecture.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Did a good job with an uninteresting topic.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Good

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  He presented the information in a concise and coherant manner, but he discussed topics that many of us already understood from either courses in undergrad or research conducted prior to graduate school.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: good to learn basics of medical ethics.
This class is a fine introduction to the reasons for ethics protections and a basic introduction to research ethics.
Required seminar. Would not otherwise take.
This has to be an entire semester course. It was a waste of time trying to consolidate all this material into two hours.
The course is required, so just get it over with
Sign in at the beginning and leave half way through.
Mandatory
Advise to fellow students: Bring your laptop or a magazine to the seminar itself.
It is short and easy to get through.
It takes 15 mins to complete all the different ethical tests. It's not a hassle at all.
required seminar.
Although a mandatory course, it is extremely informative for summer internship. In addition, it's a good way to become familiar with Kaveh - an incredible professor and individual.
A 2 hour seminar which you must take in the spring semester. simple.

It's only for one day; I feel, that while it was a good lecture, it was too short. How is it that we have other seminars/classes that go across the entire year and yet ethics is some lecture tucked into 2 hour slot?
You have to take it - it doesn't take much time and can't hurt during the job application process.
bring other classwork.

This is a one-time course to teach students about research ethics, and to teach them the proper way to coordinate research projects when human subjects are involved. I would definitely recommend this class to another student, although it is required as part of the MPH degree.
I would check out the Yale IRB website.
This is a required ethics seminar. The subject matter is important, though not the most interesting thing to listen to.
This is required, but I would recommend it to another student.
This course is a mandatory introduction to ethical issues in public health and the procedures necessary to obtain approval for research with human subjects.
not needed, it's mandatory
Informative
It's required! But it's good that we fill out the certifications.
Needed to be done
A discussion of ethical implications of research with examples followed by a question and answer period.
The course was a short but good refresher in research ethics.
Only need to do this if required. Not a good class, and it's too bad it occupies a Friday afternoon.
It's compulsory so everyone has to take it!
As above. I understand the need for the class and the need for it to be a requirement.
It's required, so everyone must take it, but tasks we simple to complete.
